017package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.oklab;
018
019import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.FloatColors;
020import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.BitConversion;
021import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.TrigTools;
022
023import java.util.Random;
024
025import static com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.oklab.Gamut.GAMUT_DATA;
026
027/**
028 * Contains code for manipulating colors as {@code int} and packed {@code float} values in the Oklab color space.
029 * Oklab is a very new color space that builds on the same foundation as IPT, but seems to be better-calibrated for
030 * uniform lightness and colorfulness, instead of just the emphasis on uniform hue that IPT has. Relative to IPT, Oklab
031 * has a noticeably smaller range in chromatic channels (IPT's protan and tritan can range past 0.8 or as low as 0.35,
032 * but the similar A and B channels in Oklab don't stray past about 0.65 at the upper end, if that), but it does this so
033 * the difference between two Oklab colors is just the Euclidean distance between their components. A slight difference
034 * between Oklab and IPT here is that IPT shrinks the chromatic channels to store their -1 to 1 range in a color float's
035 * 0 to 1 range, then offsets the shrunken range from -0.5 to 0.5, to 0 to 1; Oklab does not need to shrink the range,
036 * and only offsets it in the same way (both just add 0.5).
037 * <br>
038 * Here's <a href="https://bottosson.github.io/posts/oklab/">Bj√∂rn Ottosson's original post introducing Oklab</a>.
039 * So far, <a href="https://raphlinus.github.io/color/2021/01/18/oklab-critique.html">it stood up to analysis by Raph
040 * Levien</a>, and seems to be gaining fans quickly.
041 */
042public class ColorTools {
043        /**
044         * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, here, L (luminance or lightness), A
045         * (a chromatic component ranging from greenish to reddish, called protan in IPT), B (a chromatic component ranging
046         * from bluish to yellowish, called tritan in IPT), and alpha (or opacity). L should be
047         * between 0 and 1, inclusive, with 0 used for very dark colors (almost only black), and 1 used for very light
048         * colors (almost only white). A and B range from 0.0 to 1.0, with grayscale results when both are about 0.5.
049         * There's some aesthetic value in changing just one chroma value. When A is high and B is low, the color is more
050         * purple/magenta, when both are low it is more bluish, when B is high and A is low, the color tends to be greenish,
051         * and when both are high it tends to be orange. When A and B are both near 0.5f, the color is closer to gray.
052         * Alpha is the multiplicative opacity of the color, and acts like RGBA's alpha.
053         * <br>
054         * This method bit-masks the resulting color's byte values, so any values can technically be given to this as
055         * L, A, and B, but they will only be reversible from the returned float color to the original L,
056         * A, and B values if the original values were in the range that {@link #channelL(float)}, {@link #channelA(float)},
057         * and {@link #channelB(float)} return. You can use {@link #inGamut(float, float, float)} to check if a given set of
058         * L, A, and B values is in-gamut, that is, it can be converted to and from an RGB color without going out of the
059         * valid range. If you just want to enforce that a color is in-gamut, you can use
060         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)}, which takes the same parameters this method does, or
061         * {@link #limitToGamut(float)} if you already have a packed float color that could be out-of-gamut.
062         *
063         * @param l     0f to 1f, lightness or L component of Oklab, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
064         * @param a     0f to 1f, protan or A component of Oklab, with 1f more orange, red, or magenta
065         * @param b     0f to 1f, tritan or B component of Oklab, with 1f more green, yellow, or red
066         * @param alpha 0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque
067         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
068         */
069        public static float oklab(float l, float a, float b, float alpha) {
070                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (alpha * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (b * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
071                                | ((int) (a * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (l * 255) & 0xFF));
072        }
073
074        /**
075         * An approximation of the cube-root function for float inputs and outputs.
076         * This can be about twice as fast as {@link Math#cbrt(double)}. This
077         * version does not tolerate negative inputs, because in the narrow use
078         * case it has in this class, it is never given negative inputs.
079         * <br>
080         * Has very low relative error (less than 1E-9) when inputs are uniformly
081         * distributed between 0 and 512, and absolute mean error of less than
082         * 1E-6 in the same scenario. Uses a bit-twiddling method similar to one
083         * presented in Hacker's Delight and also used in early 3D graphics (see
084         * https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_inverse_square_root for more, but
085         * this code approximates cbrt(x) and not 1/sqrt(x)). This specific code
086         * was originally by Marc B. Reynolds, posted in his "Stand-alone-junk"
087         * repo: https://github.com/Marc-B-Reynolds/Stand-alone-junk/blob/master/src/Posts/ballcube.c#L182-L197 .
088         * It's worth noting that while hardware instructions for finding the
089         * square root of a float have gotten extremely fast, the same is not
090         * true for the cube root (which has to allow negative inputs), so while
091         * the bit-twiddling inverse square root is no longer a beneficial
092         * optimization on current hardware, this does seem to help.
093         * <br>
094         * This is used when converting from RGB to Oklab, as an intermediate step.
095         * @param x any non-negative finite float to find the cube root of
096         * @return the cube root of x, approximated
097         */
098        private static float cbrtPositive(float x) {
099                int ix = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(x);
100                final float x0 = x;
101                ix = (ix>>>2) + (ix>>>4);
102                ix += (ix>>>4);
103                ix += (ix>>>8) + 0x2A5137A0;
104                x  = BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(ix);
105                x  = 0.33333334f*(2f * x + x0/(x*x));
106                x  = 0.33333334f*(1.9999999f * x + x0/(x*x));
107                return x;
108        }
109
110        /**
111         * Used when converting from Oklab to RGB, as an intermediate step.
112         * Really just {@code x * x * x}.
113         * @param x one of the LMS Prime channels to be converted to LMS
114         * @return an LMS channel value, which can be converted to RGB
115         */
116        private static float cube(final float x) {
117                return x * x * x;
118        }
119
120        /**
121         * The same as floor() from libGDX's MathUtils class, this gets the int floor of a float between -16384 and 16384.
122         * @param f a float between -16384 and 16384
123         * @return the floor of f, as an int
124         */
125        private static int floor(final float f) {
126                return (int)(f + 0x1p14) - 0x4000;
127        }
128        /**
129         * Used when given non-linear sRGB inputs to make them linear, approximating with gamma 2.0.
130         * Really just {@code component * component}.
131         * @param component any non-linear channel of a color, to be made linear
132         * @return a linear version of component
133         */
134        private static float forwardGamma(final float component) {
135                return component * component;
136        }
137
138        /**
139         * Used to return from a linear, gamma-corrected input to an sRGB, non-linear output, using gamma 2.0.
140         * Really just gets the square root of component, as a float.
141         * @param component a linear channel of a color, to be made non-linear
142         * @return a non-linear version of component
143         */
144        private static float reverseGamma(final float component) {
145                return (float)Math.sqrt(component);
146        }
147
148        /**
149         * Changes the curve of a requested L value so that it matches the internally-used curve. This takes a curve with a
150         * very-dark area similar to sRGB (a very small one), and makes it significantly larger. This is typically used on
151         * "to Oklab" conversions.
152         * <br>
153         * Internally, this is similar to {@code (float)Math.pow(L, 1.5f)}. At one point it used a modified "Barron spline"
154         * to get its curvature mostly right, but this now seems nearly indistinguishable from an ideal curve.
155         * @param L lightness, from 0 to 1 inclusive
156         * @return an adjusted L value that can be used internally
157         */
158        public static float forwardLight(final float L) {
159                return (float) Math.sqrt(L * L * L);
160        }
161//      public static float forwardLight(final float L) {
162//              final float shape = 0.6578947368421053f, turning = 0.963f;
163//              final float d = turning - L;
164//              float r;
165//              if (d < 0)
166//                      r = ((1f - turning) * (L - 1f)) / (1f - (L + shape * d)) + 1f;
167//              else
168//                      r = (turning * L) / (1e-20f + (L + shape * d));
169//              return r * r * (256f / 255f);
170//      }
171
172//      public static float forwardLight(final float L) {
173//              return (L - 1.004f) / (1f - L * 0.4285714f) + 1.004f;
174//      }
175
176        /**
177         * Changes the curve of the internally-used lightness when it is output to another format. This makes the very-dark
178         * area smaller, matching (closely) the curve that the standard sRGB lightness uses. This is typically used on "from
179         * Oklab" conversions.
180         * <br>
181         * Internally, this is similar to {@code (float)Math.pow(L, 2f/3f)}. At one point it used a modified "Barron spline"
182         * to get its curvature mostly right, but this now seems nearly indistinguishable from an ideal curve.
183         * <br>
184         * This specific code uses a modified cube root approximation originally by Marc B. Reynolds, posted in his
185     * <a href="https://github.com/Marc-B-Reynolds/Stand-alone-junk/blob/7d8d1e19b2ab09743f46964f60244906e1023f6a/src/Posts/ballcube.c#L182-L197">"Stand-alone-junk" repo</a> .
186         * @param L lightness, from 0 to 1 inclusive
187         * @return an adjusted L value that can be fed into a conversion to RGBA or something similar
188         */
189        public static float reverseLight(float L) {
190                int ix = BitConversion.floatToIntBits(L);
191                final float x0 = L;
192                ix = (ix>>>2) + (ix>>>4);
193                ix += (ix>>>4);
194                ix += (ix>>>8) + 0x2A5137A0;
195                L = BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(ix);
196                L = 0.33333334f * (2f * L + x0 / (L * L));
197                L = 0.33333334f * (1.9999999f * L + x0 / (L * L));
198                return L * L;
199        }
200//      public static float reverseLight(float L) {
201//              L = (float) Math.sqrt(L * 0x0.ffp0f);
202//              final float shape = 1.52f, turning = 0.963f;
203//              final float d = turning - L;
204//              float r;
205//              if (d < 0)
206//                      r = ((1f - turning) * (L - 1f)) / (1f - (L + shape * d)) + 1f;
207//              else
208//                      r = (turning * L) / (1e-20f + (L + shape * d));
209//              return r;
210//      }
211
212//      public static float reverseLight(final float L) {
213//              return (L - 0.993f) / (1f + L * 0.75f) + 0.993f;
214//      }
215
216        /**
217         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)} to an RGBA8888 int.
218         * This format of int can be used with Pixmap and in some other places in libGDX.
219         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
220         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
221         */
222        public static int toRGBA8888(final float packed)
223        {
224                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
225                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
226                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
227                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
228                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
229                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
230                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
231                final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
232                final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
233                final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
234                return r << 24 | g << 16 | b << 8 | (decoded & 0xfe000000) >>> 24 | decoded >>> 31;
235        }
236
237        /**
238         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
239         * to a packed float in RGBA format.
240         * This format of float can be used with the standard SpriteBatch and in some other places in libGDX.
241         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
242         * @return a packed float color as RGBA
243         */
244        public static float toRGBA(final float packed)
245        {
246                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
247                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
248                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
249                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
250                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
251                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
252                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
253                final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
254                final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
255                final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
256                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(r | g << 8 | b << 16 | (decoded & 0xfe000000));
257        }
258
259        /**
260         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
261         * @param rgba an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
262         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
263         */
264        public static float fromRGBA8888(final int rgba) {
265                final float r = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 24) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
266                final float g = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
267                final float b = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
268
269                final float l = cbrtPositive(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
270                final float m = cbrtPositive(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
271                final float s = cbrtPositive(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
272
273                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
274                                Math.min(Math.max((int)(forwardLight
275                                                (0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s) * 255.999f         ), 0), 255)
276                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.9779984951f * l - 2.4285922050f * m + 0.4505937099f * s) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
277                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.0259040371f * l + 0.7827717662f * m - 0.8086757660f * s) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
278                                                | (rgba & 0xFE) << 24);
279        }
280
281        /**
282         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 packed float and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
283         * @param packed a packed float in RGBA8888 format, with A in the MSB and R in the LSB
284         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
285         */
286        public static float fromRGBA(final float packed) {
287                final int abgr = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
288                final float r = forwardGamma((abgr & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
289                final float g = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
290                final float b = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
291                final float l = cbrtPositive(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
292                final float m = cbrtPositive(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
293                final float s = cbrtPositive(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
294                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
295                                Math.min(Math.max((int)(forwardLight
296                                                (0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s) * 255.999f         ), 0), 255)
297                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.9779984951f * l - 2.4285922050f * m + 0.4505937099f * s) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
298                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.0259040371f * l + 0.7827717662f * m - 0.8086757660f * s) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
299                                                | (abgr & 0xFE000000));
300        }
301
302
303        /**
304         * Takes RGBA components from 0.0 to 1.0 each and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
305         * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
306         * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
307         * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
308         * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
309         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
310         */
311        public static float fromRGBA(float r, float g, float b, final float a) {
312                r = forwardGamma(r);
313                g = forwardGamma(g);
314                b = forwardGamma(b);
315                final float l = cbrtPositive(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
316                final float m = cbrtPositive(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
317                final float s = cbrtPositive(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
318                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
319                                Math.min(Math.max((int)(forwardLight
320                                                (0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s) * 255.999f         ), 0), 255)
321                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.9779984951f * l - 2.4285922050f * m + 0.4505937099f * s) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
322                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.0259040371f * l + 0.7827717662f * m - 0.8086757660f * s) * 127.5f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
323                                                | ((int)(a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
324        }
325
326        /**
327         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
328         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
329         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
330         */
331        public static int redInt(final float encoded)
332        {
333                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
334                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
335                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
336                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
337                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
338                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
339                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
340                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
341        }
342
343        /**
344         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
345         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
346         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
347         */
348        public static int greenInt(final float encoded)
349        {
350                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
351                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
352                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
353                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
354                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
355                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
356                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
357                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
358        }
359
360        /**
361         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
362         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
363         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
364         */
365        public static int blueInt(final float encoded)
366        {
367                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
368                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
369                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
370                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
371                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
372                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
373                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
374                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
375        }
376
377        /**
378         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as an even int ranging from 0 to 254, inclusive. Because
379         * of how alpha is stored in libGDX, no odd-number values are possible for alpha.
380         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
381         * @return an even int from 0 to 254, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
382         */
383        public static int alphaInt(final float encoded)
384        {
385                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24;
386        }
387
388        /**
389         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
390         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
391         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
392         */
393        public static float red(final float encoded)
394        {
395                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
396                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
397                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
398                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
399                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
400                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
401                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
402                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
403        }
404
405        /**
406         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
407         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
408         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
409         */
410        public static float green(final float encoded)
411        {
412                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
413                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
414                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
415                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
416                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
417                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
418                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
419                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
420        }
421
422        /**
423         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
424         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
425         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
426         */
427        public static float blue(final float encoded)
428        {
429                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
430                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
431                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
432                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
433                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
434                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
435                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
436                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
437        }
438
439        /**
440         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
441         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
442         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
443         */
444        public static float alpha(final float encoded)
445        {
446                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0x1.020408p-8f;
447        }
448
449        /**
450         * Gets the "chroma" or "colorfulness" of a given Oklab color. Chroma is similar to saturation in that grayscale
451         * values have 0 saturation and 0 chroma, while brighter colors have high saturation and chroma. The difference is
452         * that colors that are perceptually more-colorful have higher chroma than colors that are perceptually
453         * less-colorful, regardless of hue, whereas saturation changes its meaning depending on the hue and lightness. That
454         * is, the most saturated color for a given hue and lightness always has a saturation of 1, but if that color
455         * isn't perceptually very colorful (as is the case for very dark and very light colors), it will have a chroma that
456         * is much lower than the maximum. The result of this method can't be negative, grayscale values have very close to
457         * 0 chroma, and the most colorful values (close to cyan) should have 0.334f chroma.
458         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
459         * @return a float between 0.0f and 0.334f that represents how colorful the given value is
460         */
461        public static float chroma(final float encoded) {
462                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
463                final float a = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1FE) - 0xFF)  * 0x1p-8f;
464                final float b = ((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1FE) - 0xFF) * 0x1p-8f;
465                return (float) Math.sqrt(a * a + b * b);
466        }
467
468        /**
469         * Given a hue and lightness, this gets the (approximate) maximum chroma possible for that hue-lightness
470         * combination. This is useful to know the bounds of {@link #chroma(float)}. This should be no greater
471         * than 0.334f .
472         * @param hue the hue, typically between 0.0f and 1.0f, to look up
473         * @param lightness the lightness, clamped between 0.0f and 1.0f, to look up
474         * @return the maximum possible chroma for the given hue and lightness, between 0.0f and 0.334f
475         */
476        public static float chromaLimit(final float hue, final float lightness){
477                final int idx = (int) (Math.min(Math.max(lightness, 0f), 1f) * 255.999f) << 8
478                                | (int) (256f * (hue - floor(hue)));
479                return (GAMUT_DATA[idx]) * 0x1p-8f;
480        }
481
482        /**
483         * Gets a color as an Oklab packed float given floats representing hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
484         * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
485         * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
486         * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
487         * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
488         * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
489         * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
490         * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
491         * <br>
492         * This method considers its hue, saturation, and lightness parameters as the HSL color space does. You may instead
493         * want the method {@link #oklabByHSL(float, float, float, float)}, which treats lightness exactly as Oklab does,
494         * and handles hue and saturation with the Oklab color solid (which is shaped oddly) instead of the HSL color solid
495         * (which is a bicone, with a wide cone pointing up attached at the base to another wide cone pointing down).
496         * Using oklabByHSL() should be faster in many cases, and the lightness handling alone may be a reason to use it.
497         * There is also {@link #oklabByHCL(float, float, float, float)}, which may be preferable if you want a specific
498         * amount of chroma (colorful-ness) and no greater.
499         *
500         * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
501         * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
502         * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
503         * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
504         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
505         */
506        public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
507                if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
508                        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
509                } else {
510                        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
511                }
512        }
513
514        /**
515         * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color as HSL would calculate it, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f,
516         * inclusive. This is different from {@link #chroma(float)}; see that method's documentation for details. It is also
517         * different from {@link #oklabSaturation(float)}, which gets the saturation as Oklab understands it rather than how
518         * HSL understands it.
519         *
520         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
521         * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
522         */
523        public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
524                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
525                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
526                if(Math.abs(L - 0.5) > 0.495f) return 0f;
527                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
528                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
529                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
530                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
531                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
532                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
533                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
534                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
535                float x, y, w;
536                if(g < b) {
537                        x = b;
538                        y = g;
539                }
540                else {
541                        x = g;
542                        y = b;
543                }
544                if(r < x) {
545                        w = r;
546                }
547                else {
548                        w = x;
549                        x = r;
550                }
551                return x - Math.min(w, y);
552        }
553
554        /**
555         * Defined as per HSL; normally you only need {@link #channelL(float)} to get accurate lightness for Oklab. You can
556         * also use {@link #oklabLightness(float)}, which is an alias for channelL(). This ranges from 0.0f (black) to 1.0f
557         * (white).
558         *
559         * @param encoded a packed float Oklab color
560         * @return the lightness of the given color as HSL would calculate it
561         */
562        public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
563                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
564                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
565                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
566                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
567                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
568                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
569                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
570                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
571                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
572                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
573                float x, y, w;
574                if(g < b) {
575                        x = b;
576                        y = g;
577                }
578                else {
579                        x = g;
580                        y = b;
581                }
582                if(r < x) {
583                        w = r;
584                }
585                else {
586                        w = x;
587                        x = r;
588                }
589                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
590                return x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
591        }
592
593        /**
594         * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
595         * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased). You can also use {@link #oklabHue(float)}, which
596         * positions the different hues at different values, somewhat, from this, but is more accurate to how Oklab handles
597         * hues.
598         *
599         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
600         * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
601         * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
602         */
603        public static float hue(final float encoded) {
604                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
605                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
606                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
607                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
608                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
609                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
610                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
611                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
612                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
613                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
614                float x, y, z, w;
615                if(g < b) {
616                        x = b;
617                        y = g;
618                        z = -1f;
619                        w = 2f / 3f;
620                }
621                else {
622                        x = g;
623                        y = b;
624                        z = 0f;
625                        w = -1f / 3f;
626                }
627                if(r < x) {
628                        z = w;
629                        w = r;
630                }
631                else {
632                        w = x;
633                        x = r;
634                }
635                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
636                return Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
637        }
638
639        /**
640         * The "L" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which is its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
641         * 1.0f . You can edit the L of a color with {@link #lighten(float, float)} and {@link #darken(float, float)}.
642         *
643         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
644         * @return the L value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
645         */
646        public static float channelL(final float encoded)
647        {
648                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) / 255f;
649        }
650
651        /**
652         * The "A" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which when combined with the B channel describes the
653         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If A is 0f, the color will be cooler, more green or
654         * blue; if A is 1f, the color will be warmer, from magenta to orange. You can edit the A of a color with
655         * {@link #raiseA(float, float)} and {@link #lowerA(float, float)}.
656         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
657         * @return the A value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
658         */
659        public static float channelA(final float encoded)
660        {
661                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) / 255f;
662        }
663
664        /**
665         * The "B" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which when combined with the A channel describes the
666         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If B is 0f, the color will be more "artificial", more
667         * blue or purple; if B is 1f, the color will be more "natural", from green to yellow to orange. You can edit
668         * the B of a color with {@link #raiseB(float, float)} and {@link #lowerB(float, float)}.
669         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
670         * @return the B value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
671         */
672        public static float channelB(final float encoded)
673        {
674                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) / 255f;
675        }
676
677        /**
678         * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, lightness,
679         * and opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Note that this edits the color in HSL space, not Oklab! Takes
680         * floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity; these can be
681         * between -1f and 1f. Returns a packed float color. The float is likely to be different from the
682         * result of {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)} unless hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity are all 0.
683         * This won't allocate any objects.
684         * <br>
685         * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so that
686         * they can't go above 1 or below 0, except for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
687         * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
688         * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
689         * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
690         * <br>
691         * You may want {@link #editOklab(float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float)} instead, which
692         * adjusts the L, A, B, and alpha channels directly instead of converting to HSL and back.
693         *
694         * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
695         * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
696         * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
697         * @param light      -1f to 1f, the light/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
698         * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
699         * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
700         */
701        public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float light, float opacity) {
702                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
703                final float L = Math.min(Math.max(light + reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f), 0f), 1f);
704                opacity = Math.min(Math.max(opacity + (decoded >>> 25) * (1f / 127f), 0f), 1f);
705                if (L <= 0.001f)
706                        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x808000);
707                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
708                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
709                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
710                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
711                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
712                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
713                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
714                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
715                float x, y, z, w;
716                if(g < b) {
717                        x = b;
718                        y = g;
719                        z = -1f;
720                        w = 2f / 3f;
721                }
722                else {
723                        x = g;
724                        y = b;
725                        z = 0f;
726                        w = -1f / 3f;
727                }
728                if(r < x) {
729                        z = w;
730                        w = r;
731                }
732                else {
733                        w = x;
734                        x = r;
735                }
736                final float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
737                final float lum = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
738                hue += Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)) + 1f;
739                saturation += (x - lum) / (Math.min(lum, 1f - lum) + 1e-10f);
740                return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue - (int)hue, Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f), lum, opacity));
741        }
742
743        /**
744         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
745         * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
746         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
747         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
748         * white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
749         * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
750         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
751         * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
752         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
753         */
754        public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
755                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
756                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i + (0xFF - i) * change) & 0xFF) | other);
757        }
758
759        /**
760         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
761         * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
762         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
763         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
764         * black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
765         * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
766         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
767         * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
768         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
769         */
770        public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
771                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
772                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) | other);
773        }
774
775        /**
776         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a warmer color (orange to magenta) by change. While change
777         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully warmed), start should be a packed color, as from
778         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
779         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
780         * lerp towards a warmer color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
781         * alpha and L of start as-is.
782         * @see #lowerA(float, float) the counterpart method that cools a float color
783         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
784         * @param change how much to warm start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a warmer result
785         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a warmer color
786         */
787        public static float raiseA(final float start, final float change) {
788                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
789                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p + (0xFF - p) * change) << 8 & 0xFF00) | other);
790        }
791
792        /**
793         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a cooler color (green to blue) by change. While change
794         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as from
795         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
796         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
797         * towards a cooler color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and
798         * L of start as-is.
799         * @see #raiseA(float, float) the counterpart method that warms a float color
800         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
801         * @param change how much to cool start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a cooler result
802         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a cooler color
803         */
804        public static float lowerA(final float start, final float change) {
805                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
806                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
807        }
808
809        /**
810         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a "natural" color (between green and orange) by change.
811         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully natural), start should be a packed color, as
812         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
813         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
814         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more natural color. Unlike
815         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and L of start as-is.
816         * @see #lowerB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less natural
817         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
818         * @param change how much to change start to a natural color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more natural result
819         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more natural color
820         */
821        public static float raiseB(final float start, final float change) {
822                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
823                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 16 & 0xFF0000) | other);
824        }
825
826        /**
827         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards an "artificial" color (between blue and purple) by change.
828         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully artificial), start should be a packed color, as
829         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
830         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
831         * towards a more artificial color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
832         * alpha and L of start as-is.
833         * @see #raiseB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less artificial
834         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
835         * @param change how much to change start to a bolder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more artificial result
836         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more artificial color
837         */
838        public static float lowerB(final float start, final float change) {
839                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
840                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 | other);
841        }
842
843        /**
844         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
845         * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
846         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
847         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
848         * transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
849         * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
850         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
851         * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
852         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
853         */
854        public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
855                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
856                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
857        }
858
859        /**
860         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
861         * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
862         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
863         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
864         * transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
865         * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
866         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
867         * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
868         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
869         */
870        public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
871                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
872                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
873        }
874
875        /**
876         * Brings the chromatic components of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating them). While
877         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
878         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This only changes A and B; it leaves L and alpha alone, unlike
879         * {@link #lessenChange(float, float)}, which usually changes L.
880         * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
881         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
882         * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
883         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
884         */
885        public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
886                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start);
887                return oklab((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
888                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
889                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
890                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
891        }
892
893        /**
894         * Pushes the chromatic components of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating them). While change
895         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
896         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This changes only A and B. Higher values for {@code change} can
897         * force the color out of the gamut, which this corrects using {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)}.
898         * The alpha never changes.
899         * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
900         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
901         * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
902         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
903         */
904        public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
905                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start);
906                return limitToGamut((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
907                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
908                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
909                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
910        }
911
912        /**
913         * Given a packed float Oklab color {@code mainColor} and another Oklab color that it should be made to contrast with,
914         * gets a packed float Oklab color with roughly inverted L but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B
915         * are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white or black). This won't ever produce black or other very
916         * dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for L values between 0.5 and 0.55. That allows
917         * most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of
918         * {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the L unchanged if the chromatic channels of the
919         * contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different. This has nothing to do with the contrast
920         * channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can make too-similar lightness values further
921         * apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor} to maximize its lightness difference from
922         * {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
923         * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)};
924         *                     this is the color that will be adjusted
925         * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)};
926         *                            the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
927         * @return a different Oklab packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
928         */
929        public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
930        {
931                final int bits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
932                                contrastBits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
933                                L = (bits & 0xff),
934                                A = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
935                                B = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
936                                cL = (contrastBits & 0xff),
937                                cA = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
938                                cB = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
939                if((A - cA) * (A - cA) + (B - cB) * (B - cB) >= 0x10000)
940                        return mainColor;
941                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((bits & 0xFEFFFF00) | (int) (cL < 128 ? L * 0.45f + 140 : 127 - L * 0.45f));
942        }
943
944        /**
945         * Given a packed float Oklab color {@code mainColor} and another Oklab color that it should be made to contrast
946         * with, gets a packed float Oklab color with L that should be quite different from {@code contrastingColor}'s L,
947         * but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white
948         * or black). This allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on
949         * a background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa.
950         * <br>
951         * This is similar to {@link #inverseLightness(float, float)}, but is considerably simpler, and this method will
952         * change the lightness of mainColor when the two given colors have close lightness but distant chroma. Because it
953         * averages the original L of mainColor with the modified one, this tends to not produce harsh color changes.
954         * @param mainColor a packed Oklab float color; this is the color that will be adjusted
955         * @param contrastingColor a packed Oklab float color; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with the L of this
956         * @return a different packed Oklab float color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness
957         */
958        public static float differentiateLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
959        {
960                final int main = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor), contrast = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor);
961                return limitToGamut(BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((main & 0xFEFFFF00) | (contrast + 128 & 0xFF) + (main & 0xFF) >>> 1));
962        }
963
964        /**
965         * Pretty simple; adds 0.5 to the given color's L and wraps it around if it would go above 1.0, then averages that
966         * with the original L. This means light colors become darker, and dark colors become lighter, with almost all
967         * results in the middle-range of possible lightness.
968         * @param mainColor a packed Oklab float color
969         * @return a different packed Oklab float color, with its L channel changed and limited to the correct gamut
970         */
971        public static float offsetLightness(final float mainColor) {
972                final int oklab = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor);
973                return limitToGamut(BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((oklab & 0xFEFFFF00) | (oklab + 128 & 0xFF) + (oklab & 0xFF) >>> 1));
974        }
975
976        /**
977         * Makes the additive Oklab color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
978         * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
979         * returns {@link Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
980         * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery.
981         * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
982         * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
983         * @return an Oklab float color between gray and {@code color}
984         */
985        public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
986                final int e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color),
987                                sL = 0x80, sA = 0x80, sB = 0x80,
988                                eL = (e & 0xFF), eA = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, eB = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, eAlpha = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
989                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (sL + fraction * (eL - sL)) & 0xFF)
990                                | (((int) (sA + fraction * (eA - sA)) & 0xFF) << 8)
991                                | (((int) (sB + fraction * (eB - sB)) & 0xFF) << 16)
992                                | (eAlpha << 24));
993        }
994
995        /**
996         * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
997         * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
998         * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
999         * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
1000         * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the L, A, and B of the
1001         * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
1002         * isn't greater than the variance (this considers A and B extra-wide, going from -1 to 1, while L goes from 0 to 1,
1003         * but only internally for measuring distance).
1004         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
1005         * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
1006         * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
1007         * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
1008         */
1009        public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
1010                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color);
1011                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
1012                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
1013                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
1014                final float limit = variance * variance;
1015                float dist, x, y, z;
1016                for (int j = 0; j < 50; j++) {
1017                        x = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1018                        y = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1019                        z = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1020                        seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
1021                        dist = x * x + y * y + z * z;
1022                        if(dist <= limit && inGamut(x += L, y = (A + y) * 0.5f + 0.5f, z = (B + z) * 0.5f + 0.5f))
1023                                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE000000) | ((int)(z * 255.5f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
1024                                                | ((int)(y * 255.5f) << 8 & 0xFF00) | (int)(x * 255.5f));
1025                }
1026                return color;
1027        }
1028
1029        /**
1030         * Given a 1D int index between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive), this treats the 1D index as two parts (lightness and
1031         * hue angle, both from 0 to 255) and gets the distance from grayscale to the edge of the gamut at that lightness
1032         * and hue. The index can be constructed from a lightness value {@code L} from 0 to 255, and a hue value {@code H}
1033         * from 0 to 255 with: {@code (L << 8 | H)} or the simpler equivalent {@code (L * 256 + H)}. These assume L and H
1034         * have been limited to the 0 to 255 range already. This does not bounds-check index. Because hue is not typically
1035         * measured between 0 and 255, getting that value is a bit different; you can use
1036         * {@link TrigTools#atan2Turns(float, float)} (with an Oklab color's B for y, then its A for x) and multiply it by 256
1037         * to get H.
1038         * <br>
1039         * The distance this returns is a byte between 0 and 84 (both inclusive), as the Euclidean distance from the center
1040         * grayscale value at the lightness in the index, to the edge of the gamut at the same lightness, along the hue in
1041         * the index. This is measured in a space from -1 to 1 for both A and B, with the 0 in the center meaning grayscale,
1042         * and multiplied by 256 to get a meaningful byte value. To return to the A and B values Oklab uses here, you would
1043         * need to use some trigonometry on the hue (if it's in the 0 to 1 range, you can call
1044         * {@link TrigTools#cosTurns(float)} on the hue to almost get A, and {@link TrigTools#sinTurns(float)} to almost get B),
1045         * then multiply each of those by the distance, divide each by 256.0, and add 0.5.
1046         * <br>
1047         * Only intended for the narrow cases where external code needs read-only access to the internal Oklab gamut data.
1048         * The gamut data is quite large (it is in a 71 KB source file containing only the gamut, while the entire IPT_HQ
1049         * ColorTools file is 56 KB, and includes everything else except a gamut table), so it's better to have
1050         * direct read access to it without being able to accidentally rewrite it.
1051         * @param index must be between 0 and 65535; the upper 8 bits are lightness and the lower 8 are hue angle.
1052         * @return a byte (always between 0 and 84, inclusive) representing the Euclidean distance between a grayscale value and the most saturated value possible, using the above measurements
1053         */
1054        public static byte getRawGamutValue(int index){
1055                return GAMUT_DATA[index];
1056        }
1057
1058        /**
1059         * Returns true if the given packed float color, as Oklab, is valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
1060         * @param packed a packed float color as Oklab
1061         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
1062         */
1063        public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
1064        {
1065                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1066                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 255f;
1067                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127f) / 255f;
1068                final float g = GAMUT_DATA[(decoded & 0xff) << 8 | (int)(256f * TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A))];
1069                return g * g * 0x1p-18 + 0x1p-14 >= (A * A + B * B);
1070        }
1071
1072        /**
1073         * Returns true if the given Oklab values are valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
1074         * @param L lightness channel, as a float from 0 to 1
1075         * @param A green-to-red chromatic channel, as a float from 0 to 1
1076         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic channel, as a float from 0 to 1
1077         * @return true if the given Oklab channels can be converted back and forth to RGBA
1078         */
1079        public static boolean inGamut(float L, float A, float B)
1080        {
1081                A = ((int) (A * 255) - 127f) / 255f;
1082                B = ((int) (B * 255) - 127f) / 255f;
1083                final float g = GAMUT_DATA[((int) (L * 255) & 0xFF) << 8 | (int)(256f * TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A))];
1084                return g * g * 0x1p-18 + 0x1p-14 >= (A * A + B * B);
1085
1086                ////This was the old code for this inGamut(), which was subtly different from the other inGamut() when called
1087                /// on a packed float. The packed floats can go ever-so-slightly towards or away from the edge.
1088//              A = (A - 0.5f);
1089//              B = (B - 0.5f);
1090//              final byte g = GAMUT_DATA[((int)(L * 255.999f) << 8) | (int)(256f * TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A))];
1091//              return g * g * 0x1p-16 >= (A * A + B * B);
1092
1093        }
1094
1095        /**
1096         * Gets the color with the same L as the Oklab color stored in the given packed float, but the furthest A
1097         * B from gray possible for that lightness while keeping the same hue as the given color. This is very
1098         * similar to calling {@link #enrich(float, float)} with a very large {@code change} value.
1099         * @param packed a packed float color in Oklab format; does not need to be in-gamut
1100         * @return the color that is as far from grayscale as this can get while keeping the L and hue of packed
1101         * @see #limitToGamut(float) You can use limitToGamut() if you only want max saturation for out-of-gamut colors.
1102         */
1103        public static float maximizeSaturation(final float packed) {
1104                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1105                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f);
1106                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f);
1107                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A);
1108                final int idx = (decoded & 0xff) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1109                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f;
1110                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
1111                                (decoded & 0xFE0000FF) |
1112                                                (int) (TrigTools.sinTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 16 |
1113                                                (int) (TrigTools.cosTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 8
1114                );
1115        }
1116        /**
1117         * Gets the color with the same L as the Oklab color stored in the given packed float, but the furthest A
1118         * B from gray possible for that lightness while keeping the same hue as the given color. This is very
1119         * similar to calling {@link #enrich(float, float)} with a very large {@code change} value.
1120         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1121         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1122         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1123         * @param alpha alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1124         * @return the color that is as far from grayscale as this can get while keeping the L and hue of packed
1125         * @see #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float) You can use limitToGamut() if you only want max saturation
1126         * for out-of-gamut colors.
1127         */
1128        public static float maximizeSaturation(float L, float A, float B, float alpha) {
1129                L = Math.min(Math.max(L, 0f), 1f);
1130                A = Math.min(Math.max(A, 0f), 1f) - 0.5f;
1131                B = Math.min(Math.max(B, 0f), 1f) - 0.5f;
1132                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1133                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A);
1134                final int idx = (int) (L * 255f) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1135                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f;
1136                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
1137                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1138                                                (int) (TrigTools.sinTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 16 |
1139                                                (int) (TrigTools.cosTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 8 |
