1140                                                (int) (L * 255f));
1141        }
1142
1143        /**
1144         * Gets the hue of the given Oklab float color, but as Oklab understands hue rather than how HSL does.
1145         * This is different from {@link #hue(float)}, which uses HSL. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive)
1146         * and 1 (exclusive).
1147         *
1148         * @param packed a packed Oklab float color
1149         * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (exclusive) that represents hue in the Oklab color space
1150         */
1151        public static float oklabHue(final float packed) {
1152                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1153                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f);
1154                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f);
1155                return TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A);
1156        }
1157
1158        /**
1159         * Gets the saturation of the given Oklab float color, but as Oklab understands saturation rather than how HSL does.
1160         * Saturation here is a fraction of the chroma limit (see {@link #chromaLimit(float, float)}) for a given hue and
1161         * lightness, and is between 0 and 1 almost all the time. Saturation should always be between 0 (inclusive) and 1
1162         * (inclusive).
1163         *
1164         * @param packed a packed Oklab float color
1165         * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive) that represents saturation in the Oklab color space
1166         */
1167        public static float oklabSaturation(final float packed) {
1168                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1169                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f);
1170                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f);
1171                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A);
1172                final int idx = (decoded & 0xff) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1173                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx];
1174                return dist <= 2.5f ? 0f : (float) Math.sqrt(A * A + B * B) * 2f / (dist);
1175        }
1176
1177        /**
1178         * Gets the lightness of the given Oklab float color, but as Oklab understands lightness rather than how HSL does.
1179         * This is different from {@link #lightness(float)}, which uses HSL. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive)
1180         * and 1 (inclusive).
1181         * <br>
1182         * This is the same as {@link #channelL(float)}.
1183         *
1184         * @param packed a packed Oklab float color
1185         * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive) that represents lightness in the Oklab color space
1186         */
1187        public static float oklabLightness(final float packed){
1188                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed) & 0xff) / 255f;
1189        }
1190
1191        /**
1192         * A different way to specify an Oklab color, using hue, saturation, lightness, and alpha like a normal HSL(A) color
1193         * but calculating them directly in the Oklab color space. This is more efficient than
1194         * {@link #floatGetHSL(float, float, float, float)}, but for colors with less than 0.5f lightness, it can be very
1195         * unpredictable in how it handles saturation. Most colors between 0.5 and 0.75 hue that also have less than 0.5
1196         * lightness are extremely desaturated and close to gray, regardless of what you give for saturation, and these
1197         * colors suddenly jump to very saturated around 0.75 hue and higher. To avoid this issue, you may prefer using
1198         * {@link #oklabByHCL(float, float, float, float)}, which takes an absolute chroma as opposed to the saturation here
1199         * (which is a fraction of the maximum chroma).
1200         * <br>
1201         * Note that this takes a different value for its {@code hue} that the method {@link #hue(float)} produces, just
1202         * like its {@code saturation} and the method {@link #saturation(float)}, and {@code lightness} and the method
1203         * {@link #lightness(float)}. The hue is just distributed differently, and the lightness should be equivalent to
1204         * {@link #channelL(float)}, but the saturation here refers to what fraction the chroma should be of the maximum
1205         * chroma for the given hue and lightness. You can use {@link #oklabHue(float)}, {@link #oklabSaturation(float)},
1206         * and {@link #oklabLightness(float)} to get the hue, saturation, and lightness values from an existing color that
1207         * this will understand ({@link #alpha(float)} too).
1208         * @param hue between 0 and 1, usually, but this will automatically wrap if too high or too low
1209         * @param saturation will be clamped between 0 and 1
1210         * @param lightness will be clamped between 0 and 1
1211         * @param alpha will be clamped between 0 and 1
1212         * @return a packed Oklab float color that tries to match the requested hue, saturation, and lightness
1213         */
1214        public static float oklabByHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float alpha) {
1215                lightness = Math.min(Math.max(lightness, 0f), 1f);
1216                saturation = Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f);
1217                hue -= floor(hue);
1218                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1219                final int idx = (int) (lightness * 255.999f) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1220                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * saturation * 0.5f;
1221                return limitToGamut(BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
1222                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1223                                                (int) (TrigTools.sinTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 16 |
1224                                                (int) (TrigTools.cosTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 8 |
1225                                                (int) (lightness * 255.999f)));
1226        }
1227
1228        /**
1229         * A different way to specify an Oklab color, using hue, chroma, lightness, and alpha something like a normal HSL(A)
1230         * color but calculating them directly in the Oklab color space. This has you specify the desired chroma directly,
1231         * as obtainable with {@link #chroma(float)}, rather than the saturation, which is a fraction of the maximum chroma
1232         * (saturation is what {@link #oklabByHSL(float, float, float, float)} uses). Note that this takes a different value
1233         * for its {@code hue} that the method {@link #hue(float)} produces, just like {@code lightness} and the method
1234         * {@link #lightness(float)}. The hue is just distributed differently, and the lightness should be equivalent to
1235         * {@link #channelL(float)}. If you use this to get two colors with the same chroma and lightness, but different
1236         * hue, then the resulting colors should have similar colorfulness unless one or both chroma values exceeded the
1237         * gamut limit (you can get this limit with {@link #chromaLimit(float, float)}). If a chroma value given is greater
1238         * than the chroma limit, this clamps chroma to that limit. You can use {@link #oklabHue(float)},
1239         * {@link #chroma(float)}, and {@link #oklabLightness(float)} to get the hue, chroma, and lightness values from an
1240         * existing color that this will understand ({@link #alpha(float)} too).
1241         * @param hue between 0 and 1, usually, but this will automatically wrap if too high or too low
1242         * @param chroma will be clamped between 0 and the maximum chroma possible for the given hue and lightness
1243         * @param lightness will be clamped between 0 and 1
1244         * @param alpha will be clamped between 0 and 1
1245         * @return a packed Oklab float color that tries to match the requested hue, chroma, and lightness
1246         */
1247        public static float oklabByHCL(float hue, float chroma, float lightness, float alpha) {
1248                lightness = Math.min(Math.max(lightness, 0f), 1f);
1249                chroma = Math.max(chroma, 0f);
1250                hue -= floor(hue);
1251                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1252                final int idx = (int) (lightness * 255.999f) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1253                final float dist = Math.min(chroma * 127.5f, GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f);
1254                return limitToGamut(BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
1255                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1256                                                (int) (TrigTools.sinTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 16 |
1257                                                (int) (TrigTools.cosTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 8 |
1258                                                (int) (lightness * 255.999f)));
1259        }
1260
1261        /**
1262         * Checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut; if it isn't in-gamut, brings the color just inside
1263         * the gamut at the same lightness, or if it is already in-gamut, returns the color as-is.
1264         * @param packed a packed float color in Oklab format; often this color is not in-gamut
1265         * @return the first color this finds that is in-gamut, as if it was moving toward a grayscale color with the same L
1266         * @see #inGamut(float) You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1267         */
1268        public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
1269                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1270                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f);
1271                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f);
1272                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A);
1273                final int idx = (decoded & 0xff) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1274                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f;
1275                if (dist * dist >= (A * A + B * B))
1276                        return packed;
1277                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
1278                                (decoded & 0xFE0000FF) |
1279                                                (int) (TrigTools.sinTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 16 |
1280                                                (int) (TrigTools.cosTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 8
1281                );
1282        }
1283
1284        /**
1285         * Checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut; if it isn't in-gamut, brings the color just inside
1286         * the gamut at the same lightness, or if it is already in-gamut, returns the color as-is. This always produces
1287         * an opaque color.
1288         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1289         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1290         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1291         * @return the first color this finds that is in-gamut, as if it was moving toward a grayscale color with the same L
1292         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1293         */
1294        public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B) {
1295                return limitToGamut(L, A, B, 1f);
1296        }
1297        /**
1298         * Checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut; if it isn't in-gamut, brings the color just inside
1299         * the gamut at the same lightness, or if it is already in-gamut, returns the color as-is.
1300         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1301         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1302         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1303         * @param alpha alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1304         * @return the first color this finds that is in-gamut, as if it was moving toward a grayscale color with the same L
1305         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1306         */
1307        public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B, float alpha) {
1308                L = Math.min(Math.max(L, 0f), 1f);
1309                A = Math.min(Math.max(A, 0f), 1f);
1310                B = Math.min(Math.max(B, 0f), 1f);
1311                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1312                final float A2 = ((int) (A * 255) - 127f) / 255f;
1313                final float B2 = ((int) (B * 255) - 127f) / 255f;
1314                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2Turns(B2, A2);
1315                final int idx = (int) (L * 255f) << 8 | (int)(256f * hue);
1316                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f;
1317                if(dist * dist * 0x1p-16f >= (A2 * A2 + B2 * B2))
1318                        return oklab(L, A, B, alpha);
1319                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
1320                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1321                                                (int) (TrigTools.sinTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 16 |
1322                                                (int) (TrigTools.cosTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 8 |
1323                                                (int) (L * 255f));
1324        }
1325
1326        /**
1327         * Given a packed float Oklab color, this edits its L, A, B, and alpha channels by adding the corresponding "add"
1328         * parameter and then clamping. This returns a different float value (of course, the given float can't be edited
1329         * in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged. This clamps the
1330         * resulting color to remain in-gamut, so it should be safe to convert it back to RGBA.
1331         * @param encoded a packed float Oklab color
1332         * @param addL how much to add to the L channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1333         * @param addA how much to add to the A channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1334         * @param addB how much to add to the B channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1335         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1336         * @return a packed float Oklab color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
1337         */
1338        public static float editOklab(float encoded, float addL, float addA, float addB, float addAlpha) {
1339                return editOklab(encoded, addL, addA, addB, addAlpha, 1f, 1f, 1f, 1f);
1340        }
1341        /**
1342         * Given a packed float Oklab color, this edits its L, A, B, and alpha channels by first multiplying each channel by
1343         * the corresponding "mul" parameter and then adding the corresponding "add" parameter, before clamping. This means
1344         * the lightness value {@code L} is multiplied by {@code mulL}, then has {@code addL} added, and then is clamped to
1345         * the normal range for L (0 to 1). This returns a different float value (of course, the given float can't be edited
1346         * in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged, or a value of 1 for any
1347         * "mul" parameter that shouldn't change. Note that this manipulates A and B in the -0.5 to 0.5 range, so if you
1348         * multiply by a small number like {@code 0.25f}, then this will produce a less-saturated color, and if you multiply
1349         * by a larger number like {@code 4f}, then you will get a much more-saturated color. This clamps the resulting
1350         * color to remain in-gamut, so it should be safe to convert it back to RGBA.
1351         * @param encoded a packed float Oklab color
1352         * @param addL how much to add to the L channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1353         * @param addA how much to add to the A channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1354         * @param addB how much to add to the B channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1355         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1356         * @param mulL how much to multiply the L channel by; should be non-negative
1357         * @param mulA how much to multiply the A channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
1358         * @param mulB how much to multiply the B channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
1359         * @param mulAlpha how much to multiply the alpha channel by; should be non-negative
1360         * @return a packed float Oklab color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
1361         */
1362        public static float editOklab(float encoded, float addL, float addA, float addB, float addAlpha,
1363                                                                  float mulL, float mulA, float mulB, float mulAlpha) {
1364                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
1365                float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
1366                float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
1367                float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
1368                float alpha = (decoded >>> 25) / 127f;
1369
1370                L = Math.min(Math.max(L * mulL + addL, 0f), 1f);
1371                A = Math.min(Math.max(A * mulA + addA * 2f, -1f), 1f) * 0.5f;
1372                B = Math.min(Math.max(B * mulB + addB * 2f, -1f), 1f) * 0.5f;
1373                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha * mulAlpha + addAlpha, 0f), 1f);
1374                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A);
1375                final int idx = (int) (L * 255f) << 8 | (int)(256f * hue);
1376                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f;
1377                if(dist * dist * 0x1p-16f >= (A * A + B * B))
1378                        return oklab(L, A + 0.5f, B + 0.5f, alpha);
1379                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
1380                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1381                                                (int) (TrigTools.sinTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 16 |
1382                                                (int) (TrigTools.cosTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 8 |
1383                                                (int) (L * 255f));
1384        }
1385
1386        /**
1387         * Multiplies the A and B channels of {@code encoded} by {@code mul}. Typically, mul is non-negative, but if it is
1388         * negative, that will do some amount of inversion of A and B.
1389         * @param encoded a packed float color
1390         * @param mul how much to multiply the chromatic channels of {@code encoded} by
1391         * @return a packed float color that should already be in-gamut
1392         */
1393        public static float multiplyChroma(float encoded, float mul) {
1394                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
1395                float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
1396                float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
1397                float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
1398                float alpha = (decoded >>> 25) / 127f;
1399
1400                A = Math.min(Math.max(A * mul, -1f), 1f) * 0.5f;
1401                B = Math.min(Math.max(B * mul, -1f), 1f) * 0.5f;
1402                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2Turns(B, A);
1403                final int idx = (int) (L * 255f) << 8 | (int)(256f * hue);
1404                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * 0.5f;
1405                if(dist * dist * 0x1p-16f >= (A * A + B * B))
1406                        return oklab(L, A + 0.5f, B + 0.5f, alpha);
1407                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
1408                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1409                                                (int) (TrigTools.sinTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 16 |
1410                                                (int) (TrigTools.cosTurns(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 8 |
1411                                                (int) (L * 255f));
1412        }
1413
1414        /**
1415         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
1416         * @param random a Random object (preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.github.tommyettinger.digital.AlternateRandom})
1417         * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1418         */
1419        public static float randomColor(Random random) {
1420                float L = random.nextFloat();
1421                float A = random.nextFloat();
1422                float B = random.nextFloat();
1423                while (!inGamut(L, A, B)) {
1424                        L = random.nextFloat();
1425                        A = random.nextFloat();
1426                        B = random.nextFloat();
1427                }
1428                return oklab(L, A, B, 1f);
1429        }
1430
1431        /**
1432         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
1433         * This is only present for legacy compatibility; new code should use {@link #randomColor(Random)}.
1434         * @param random a Random object (or preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.github.tommyettinger.digital.AlternateRandom})
1435         * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1436         * @deprecated Use {@link #randomColor(Random)} instead.
1437         */
1438        @Deprecated
1439        public static float randomizedColor(Random random) {
1440                float L = random.nextFloat();
1441                float A = random.nextFloat();
1442                float B = random.nextFloat();
1443                while (!inGamut(L, A, B)) {
1444                        L = random.nextFloat();
1445                        A = random.nextFloat();
1446                        B = random.nextFloat();
1447                }
1448                return oklab(L, A, B, 1f);
1449        }
1450
1451
1452        /**
1453         * Gets the squared Euclidean distance between two colors as packed Oklab floats. This is a very approximate measure
1454         * of how different two colors are from each other, but in Oklab this measurement is relatively more accurate than
1455         * if you used plain RGB as the color space, or even IPT_HQ. The result should typically be rather small; lightness
1456         * can only be 1 unit of distance apart at most (from black to white), and the A and B channels are usually just a
1457         * tiny bit away from the vertical lightness axis. A result of 1 may be the largest this can produce, but it is very
1458         * possible that somewhat larger results can happen. Note that this is squared, so it isn't an admissible metric for
1459         * some usage, like summing up distances.
1460         * @param encodedA a packed Oklab float
1461         * @param encodedB a packed Oklab float
1462         * @return the squared Euclidean distance between encodedA and encodedB; usually less than 1.0f
1463         */
1464        public static float distanceSquared(final float encodedA, final float encodedB) {
1465                final int decodedA = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encodedA);
1466                final float LA = reverseLight((decodedA & 0xff) / 255f);
1467                final float AA = ((decodedA >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f;
1468                final float BA = ((decodedA >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f;
1469                final int decodedB = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encodedB);
1470                final float LDiff = reverseLight((decodedB & 0xff) / 255f) - LA;
1471                final float ADiff = ((decodedB >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 127f - AA;
1472                final float BDiff = ((decodedB >>> 16 & 255) - 127f) / 127f - BA;
1473                return LDiff * LDiff + ADiff * ADiff + BDiff * BDiff;
1474        }
1475
1476        /**
1477         * Gets the actual Euclidean distance between two colors as packed Oklab floats. This is an approximate measure
1478         * of how different two colors are from each other, but in Oklab this measurement is relatively more accurate than
1479         * if you used plain RGB as the color space, or even IPT_HQ. The result should typically be rather small; lightness
1480         * can only be 1 unit of distance apart at most (from black to white), and the A and B channels are usually just a
1481         * tiny bit away from the vertical lightness axis. A result of 1 may be the largest this can produce, but it is very
1482         * possible that somewhat larger results can happen.
1483         * @param encodedA a packed Oklab float
1484         * @param encodedB a packed Oklab float
1485         * @return the Euclidean distance between encodedA and encodedB; usually less than 1.0f
1486         */
1487        public static float distance(final float encodedA, final float encodedB) {
1488                return (float) Math.sqrt(distanceSquared(encodedA, encodedB));
1489        }
1490
1491}
